frontmatter.title: Rebus
frontmatter.description: The IBM logo is one of our most valuable corporate assets and is among the most recognized identities in the world. It's the tangible symbol of our brand.

internal.content:
--- title: Rebus description: The IBM logo is one of our most valuable corporate assets and is among the most recognized identities in the world. It's the tangible symbol of our brand. --- Designed in 1981 by Paul Rand for his Eye-Bee-M poster in support of the IBM THINK motto, the rebus used pictures to represent letters. This rebus is now an iconic part of our visual history and in the permanent collection at the Museum of Modern Art in New York. IBM rebus IBM totem rebus IBM classic rebus Color Usage ## Resources Internal IBM logo request
(IBM ID required)} href="https://www.ibm.com/brand/ibm-logos/logo-requests" > ![ibm logo](../../images/resource-cards/ibm.svg) ## IBM rebus Today we still use the rebus, which has since been adjusted to meet the requirements of different mediums, scales and production environments. Like the 8-bar logo, the rebus comes in positive and reversed versions. The rebus can be used in special applications, such as merchandise, badges and events, but shouldn’t be used in place of the 8-bar logo as an official brand communications sign off. ![IBM rebus in black on white background](/images/rebus-light.svg) ![IBM rebus reversed on black background](/images/rebus-dark.svg) ## IBM totem rebus The totem rebus adds more meaning to the already lovable original. The totem connects with us because it speaks to the human factor, the user, and the ever-evolving relationship between mankind and machines. It reminds us that good design should primarily serve people and move us toward progress. ![rebus totem scale](/images/rebus-totem-scale.svg) Same scale in vertical relationship ![rebus totem positive](/images/rebus-totem-positive.svg) Totem rebus positive ![rebus totem negative](/images/rebus-totem-negative.svg) Totem rebus reversed ![rebus spacing on grid](/images/rebus-spacing-grid.svg) Rebus and spacing are on a grid ## IBM classic rebus The classic rebus, using the original color scheme, is still used for our heritage merchandise and can also be used for special occasions with permission from the brand team. This special art may only be used on a black background. This color scheme is not meant for standard usage and doesn’t reflect the current IBM brand color palette. So, while the classic rebus is available for restricted use on merchandise or for special events, prior approval is required. ![good use of the classic rebus](images/rebusclassic1.svg) ![wrong use of the classic rebus](images/rebusclassic2.svg) ## Color The IBM core colors, consisting of the blue and gray families, are used when applying color specifically to the rebus. Please refer to the [color specifications](/color#specifications) for precise values. Here are a few examples of possible color combinations using core colors and positive and negative IBM rebuses. ![color palette](/images/core_color_palette_mobile.png) ![color palette](/images/core_color_palette.png) Positive rebus ![Black on Gray 30](/images/rebus_black_on_gray30.svg) Black / Gray 30 ![Blue 70 on Blue 20](/images/rebus_blue70_on_blue20.svg) Blue 70 / Blue 20 ![Gray 60 on White](/images/rebus_gray60_on_white.svg) Gray 60 / White Reversed rebus ![Blue 50 on Black](/images/rebus_blue50_on_black.svg) Blue 50 / Black ![Blue 40 on Blue 90 ](/images/rebus_blue40_on_blue90.svg) Blue 40 / Blue 90 ![Gray 10 on Blue 60 ](/images/rebus_gray10_on_blue60.svg) Gray 10 / Blue 60 ### Background colors Dark or light background colors work well with the core colors of the IBM rebus. Always use a minimum of five “steps” away between the foreground and background color to insure appropriate contrast and legibility. Any background color from the [IDL color palette](/color#the-palette) with sufficient contrast may be used with a core color rebus. Here are a few examples of possible color combinations. Positive rebus ![Gray 100 on Blue 20](/images/rebus_gray100_on_blue20.svg) Gray 100 / Blue 20 ![Blue 70 on Green 10](/images/rebus_blue70_on_green10.svg) Blue 70 / Green 10 ![Blue 80 on Purple 30](/images/rebus_blue80_on_purple30.svg) Blue 80 / Purple 30 Reversed rebus ![Blue 40 on Purple 90](/images/rebus_blue40_on_purple90.svg) Blue 40 / Purple 90 ![Gray 10 on Teal 90](/images/rebus_gray10_on_teal90.svg) Gray 10 / Teal 90 ![White on Magenta 60](/images/rebus_white_on_magenta60.svg) White / Magenta 60 ## Usage The IBM rebus is a special piece of design. The form shouldn’t be altered, adjusted or colored in inappropriate ways. Here are a few samples of what to avoid and what’s permissible. If these basics are adhered to, it will protect the integrity of Paul Rand’s great design work. ### Clear space Keep the rebus and totem rebus separated from other visual elements by a distance equal to the M height. This distance is considered the minimum uninterrupted space surrounding the rebus. We call it the area of isolation, or clear space, and it should be adhered to in most situations. ![IBM rebus showing proper clear space ratio](images/rebus_clearspace.svg) ### Misuse Shown here are a few examples of improper use of the rebus and totem rebus. ![don’t alter the spacing of elements example](images/rebusdont_alterspacing.svg) ![don’t scale or recompose rebus elements example](images/rebus-usage-dont-recompose.svg) ![rebus don't add dropshadow example](images/rebus-usage-dont-stretch.svg) ![don’t create compositions from the rebus and the 8-bar logo example](images/rebusdont_compositions.svg) ![do not use unacceptable combos example](images/rebus-usage-dont-dropshadow.svg) ![don’t use unacceptable color combinations example](images/rebus-usage-dont-unacceptable-combos.svg) ![don’t replace the 8-bar logo with the rebus for sign offs example](images/rebusdont_signoff.svg) ![do not use unacceptable combos example](images/rebusdont_bus.svg) ### Patterns Patterns can be useful tools in a variety of graphic applications. In the workplace for example, distraction patterns on glass walls and doors can prevent injury. Event structure facades might use graphic wallcovering. They can also be used effectively on merchandise. There are a few approved patterns based on the rebus, with positive and reversed options. ![rebus pattern](/images/rebus_pattern1.png) ![rebus pattern](/images/rebus_pattern2.png) ![rebus pattern](/images/rebus_pattern3.png) ![Box Icon](../../images/resource-cards/box.png) ### The rebus in action ![rebus in an atrium](/images/rebusgallery_atrium.png) ![rebus on a notebook](/images/rebusgallery_notebook.png) ![rebus on a tshirt](/images/rebusgallery_tshirt.png) ![rebus at the us open](/images/rebusgallery_usopen.png) ![rebus on a site](/images/rebusgallery_designsite.png) ![rebus at event](/images/rebusgallery_event.png) ![rebus on a wall](/images/rebusgallery_interior.png) ![rebus pattern on glass](/images/rebusgallery_glass.png)
